p: The spatial distribution and exploitation of S. maderensis, as well as its growth and reproductive patterns, are closely related to the dynamics of the upwelling systems [ 6]. Adaptation of the biological parameters of the species to environments with different upwelling intensity should be expected. On the northwest African coast, the upwelling is stronger than in the other areas, permanent in the north of Mauritania and from November to May further south in Senegalese waters. The results were also compared with earlier measurements for Senegal to determine whether the biological parameters had changed with an increase in SST of 0.03Â°C per year over the past 30 years [ 14] and with the dramatic increase in fishing pressure, with annual landings increasing ten-fold from ~10 000 tons in 1980 to 128 700 tons in 2012 [ 2].
